    analytical

    analytical.Rmd
    library(sysrevdata)
library(tidyverse)

    Machine-structured data

    When releasing results for publication it is commmon to consider how to facilitate human interpretation through tables and visualisations. In addition, we recommend releasing data in a raw machine-readable format, with as little condensing as is realistic. Condensing data may prove to be an obstacle for extracting variables of interest by some researcher in the future.

    Example

    Here we consider an example dataset…

    todo: citation

    The first 12 columns are all different variables.

    names(bufferstrips) %>% head(12)
#>  [1] "item_id"                     "short_title"                
#>  [3] "title"                       "year"                       
#>  [5] "period"                      "google_scholar_link"        
#>  [7] "vegetated_strip_description" "nation"                     
#>  [9] "study_country"               "study_location"             
#> [11] "latitute"                    "longitude"

    However, from there the columns are mostly structured wide in groups: the first string indicates the group; the second string, the subcategory in the group, such as spatialscale.

    names(bufferstrips)[13:30]
#>  [1] "studydesign_observational"       "studydesign_manipulative"       
#>  [3] "Study length (years)"            "Time since intervention (years)"
#>  [5] "spatialscale_plot"               "spatialscale_field"             
#>  [7] "spatialscale_farm"               "spatialscale_catchment"         
#>  [9] "spatialscale_regional"           "spatialscale_notdescribed"      
#> [11] "measurementquarter_Q1"           "measurementquarter_Q2"          
#> [13] "measurementquarter_Q3"           "measurementquarter_Q4"          
#> [15] "measurementquarter_notdescribed" "farmingsystem_conventional"     
#> [17] "farmingsystem_organic"           "farmingsystem_notdescribed"
    
pivoted_bufferstrips <-
pivot_longer(
  data = bufferstrips,
  cols = -c(1:12, 15, 16),
  names_to = c("category", "subcategory"),
  names_sep = "_",
  values_drop_na = TRUE
) %>% 
  select(-value) %>% 
  janitor::clean_names()

    Dropping some of the identifying columns

    pivoted_bufferstrips %>% 
  select(1,2,3,15, 16)
#> # A tibble: 13,358 x 5
#>     item_id short_title  title                         category      subcategory
